Many agriculture fields, mainly corn, were flattened within the swaths of strongest winds. Initial estimates suggest at least 850,000 acres of partial or complete crop loss occurred from this event. Within urban and wooded areas extensive tree and structure damage was seen, including complete roof failure in a few instances. At its peak, total estimated customers without power exceeded 1.4 million across the affected states. In total, early estimates on losses (agriculture, infrastructure, private property) have exceeded $7.5 billion across the states affected. ||Environment: Broadly speaking, it was a ripe day for thunderstorms across the affected area with MUCAPE values often exceeding 3500-4000 J/kg by the mid morning hours concurrent with mid-upper level short wave support, and indications that any cold pool development would be strong (difference between cold pool and ambient air) and potentially long lived. For detailed environmental analysis, including soundings, please view the various local NWS office event review pages: NWS Des Moines, NWS Quad Cities, NWS Chicago, NWS Milwaukee, NWS Central Illinois, NWS Northern Indiana, or NWS Indianapolis.||Additional Details: Numerous injuries occurred during the derecho and in the aftermath during cleanup, including 4 direct and indirect deaths of which 3 occurred in Iowa (two in Poweshiek County and one in Linn County) and 1 in Indiana (Fort Wayne).||Disclaimer: The August 10, 2020 derecho resulted in widespread high-end damage across large portions of central and southern Iowa. Given the size and scope of the event and understanding that final damage and loss estimates (agriculture, infrastructure, and private property) will take months to complete, the NWS is not able to estimate the monetary impact at this time. Values may be added as more data becomes from various sources in future months.

A combination of an upper level trough moving northwest across the state, coupled with a strong surface pressure gradient, led to numerous reports of high wind gusts across  the region.  Most of the wind damage occurred with the passage of a rare derecho; a large fast-moving complex of thunderstorms with powerful straight-line winds.  In addition, strong wind gusts from 59 to 71 mph not associated with the derecho, occurred prior to and following the passage of this system over the urban corridor and plains of northeast Colorado.||By midday the derecho, which originated over the Great Basin, moved over the northern and central mountains, and then rapidly northeast across the I-25 corridor by mid afternoon.  These storms then tracked across the plains from late afternoon into the early evening hours.  Wind gusts from 60 to 80 mph were common with a few gusts exceeding 90 mph.  The highest gust observed was 110 mph, at the Winter Park Ski area, around 12000 feet.  Xcel Energy said in a press release that more than 208,000 customers lost power because of the storm statewide. The intense wind toppled a billboard that crashed onto Denver bakery.  Two delivery trucks parked nearby were heavily damaged.  Two injuries occurred in Denver, one seriously.  A man and his nine-year-old daughter were injured by a fallen tree.  They were standing in front of a family member���s house when the incident occurred.  The tree impaled the father through his back and he required several surgeries.  His daughter sustained cuts and bruises that required stitches.

event_narrative: The ITWS at the Orlando International Airport measured a peak wind gust of 54 knots from the northwest.
episode_narrative: Afternoon thunderstorms that developed along the sea breeze collision became severe, producing large hail in Volusia County, and damaging winds in Volusia and Orange Counties.

A strong storm system moved across the area the afternoon of the 8th into the morning of the 9th.  This system produced severe thunderstorms and high winds, across northeast Colorado, with snow across the mountains, valley areas and higher foothills.  In addition rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches occurred across the plains.   Storm totals included:  15 inches, 9 miles south-southeast of Gould and 7 miles northwest of Red Feather Lakes; 11 inches near Cameron Pass; with 4 to 10 inches elsewhere.  Strong northwest winds developed across the northeast plains on the evening of the 8th into the early morning hours of the 9th, with peak gusts from 58 to 71 mph.  ||Severe thunderstorms  on the evening of the 8th, produced powerful and destructive wind gusts along with nickel to quarter size hail, over portions of northeast Colorado.  Peak wind gusts up to 80 mph occurred, with localized gusts from 100 to 113 mph, in and near Akron.  The swath of damaging winds extended from central Washington County into Logan County and across western areas of Phillips and Sedgwick counties.  Widespread crop and property damage was observed.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS station SD519 9 miles east of Davis measured a peak wind gust of 58 mph.
episode_narrative: Additional severe thunderstorms developed near a slowly advancing cold front during the late afternoon and evening hours across southeast South Dakota.  MLCAPE reached a bit over 1000 J/kg with marginal deep-layer shear at around 30 knots.

event_narrative: A personal weather station measured an 80 mph wind gust.
episode_narrative: Additional severe thunderstorms developed near a slowly advancing cold front during the late afternoon and evening hours across southeast South Dakota.  MLCAPE reached a bit over 1000 J/kg with marginal deep-layer shear at around 30 knots.

event_narrative: Wind gust of 65 mph was measured by a personal weather station.
episode_narrative: Scattered thunderstorms developed along a weak convergence axis across central South Dakota in the late afternoon hours. Slow moving storms made use of up to 3000 J/kg MLCAPE and marginal deep-layer shear around 30 knots to produce considerable large hail and spotty damaging winds through early evening.

event_narrative: Measured gust at Rutgers Agricultural Research and Extension Center in Upper Deerfield, NJ.
episode_narrative: An impulse riding along a west to east boundary stalled near the Mason-Dixon line produced severe thunderstorms and heavy rain across sections of South Jersey from late afternoon through the evening hours on August 7th. Strong winds knocked down trees, and torrential downpours on ground already saturated from the remnants of Hurricane Isaias produced flash flooding on many roadways and small streams in the area.

event_narrative: A 69 MPH thunderstorm wind gust measured on Route 77 at mile marker 9.
episode_narrative: An impulse riding along a west to east boundary stalled near the Mason-Dixon line produced severe thunderstorms and heavy rain across sections of South Jersey from late afternoon through the evening hours on August 7th. Strong winds knocked down trees, and torrential downpours on ground already saturated from the remnants of Hurricane Isaias produced flash flooding on many roadways and small streams in the area.

event_narrative: Measured by NJWeathernet site NJ67.
episode_narrative: A strong cold front along with a mid-level shortwave trough approached the mid-Atlantic on August 25. Ahead of the disturbances, wind shear increased significantly and surface temperatures warmed, increasing instability. While some ingredients were in place for a major severe weather event, an offset in timing between the shortwave and the front, combined with greater than expected mid-level dry air, caused storms to generally struggle to develop over the mid-Atlantic. Greater storm coverage was found in more favorable environments over both New England and the Ohio Valley. However, the environment over the mid-Atlantic was still highly favorable for damaging winds, so the few storms that did develop produced some instances of wind damage.

event_narrative: Mesonet station at location recorded a 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust at start time and a 58 mph thunderstorm wind gust at end time.
episode_narrative: Evening thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front in Northwestern Kansas. These thunderstorms yielded damaging wind gusts up to 100 mph and pea size hail.

event_narrative: KHLC ASOS recorded 61 mph thunderstorm wind gusts at start and end times at location.
episode_narrative: Evening thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front in Northwestern Kansas. These thunderstorms yielded damaging wind gusts up to 100 mph and pea size hail.

event_narrative: KMCK ASOS reported a 63 mph wind gust at location.
episode_narrative: A line of thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front moving eastward through southwestern Nebraska. These thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts with speeds up to 74 mph.

event_narrative: Texas Tech West Texas Mesonet located just northwest of Haskell measured a wind gust to 63 mph.
episode_narrative: An unusual strong Canadian Cold Front and an upper level low parked across the Four Corners resulted in very heavy rainfall in a short period time and a few severe weather reports in portions of the northern Big Country.  This heavy rain flooded low water crossings and even U.S. 277 across the region and caused Lake Stamford to flood.  Two occupants in a vehicle went missing on September 9.  They both drowned as they attempted to cross a flooded low water crossing on Red Mud Creek in Jones County.  One body was recovered on September 10 and the other was recovered on September 16.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS site SD554 measured a peak wind gust of 60 mph.
episode_narrative: Storms developing along a nearly stationary frontal boundary through central South Dakota and Nebraska organized into a line by late evening.  The environment with extreme mid-level instability (greater than 9 degrees C/km) and 1200-1500 J/kg DCAPE helped to enhance damaging wind gusts across southeast South Dakota into northwest Iowa.

A weak surface boundary served as a focus for thunderstorm development during the afternoon of the 16th across southern Oklahoma and western north Texas with numerous severe wind and hail reports were received.

event_narrative: Weatherflow site XNSB in New Smyrna Beach measured a peak wind gust of 70 mph from the north.
episode_narrative: Numerous thunderstorms developed along outflow boundary and sea breeze collisions. These storms produced two tornadoes in western Volusia County, including a rare August EF-2. In addition, other thunderstorms produced strong winds and hail along the Volusia and Brevard County coasts.

event_narrative: Norfolk Airport measured a wind gust of 60 mph.
episode_narrative: A strong line of storms developed near south central South Dakota and tracked southeast producing wind damage with gusts over 60 mph in Madison, Stanton, and Cuming counties.

event_narrative: Personal weather station KSDPLANK3 measured a peak wind gust of 68 mph.
episode_narrative: Storms developing along a nearly stationary frontal boundary through central South Dakota and Nebraska organized into a line by late evening.  The environment with extreme mid-level instability (greater than 9 degrees C/km) and 1200-1500 J/kg DCAPE helped to enhance damaging wind gusts across southeast South Dakota into northwest Iowa.

event_narrative: Personal weather station KSDWESSI5 measured a peak wind gust of 60 mph.
episode_narrative: Storms developing along a nearly stationary frontal boundary through central South Dakota and Nebraska organized into a line by late evening.  The environment with extreme mid-level instability (greater than 9 degrees C/km) and 1200-1500 J/kg DCAPE helped to enhance damaging wind gusts across southeast South Dakota into northwest Iowa.

event_narrative: Automated weather station K9V9 measured a peak wind of 61 mph.
episode_narrative: Lift associated with a jet streak across southern North Dakota interacted with an unstable and weakly capped environment with 30 to 40 knots of deep-layer shear to produce a couple of smaller clusters of thunderstorms with large hail and damaging wind during the evening and overnight which progressed east and southeast across southeast South Dakota.  The final cluster was a larger-scale bowing segment which produced damaging wind gusts across south central South Dakota.  Repeated storms with heavy rainfall resulted in spotty flash flooding.

During the late morning of Saturday, July 11th, several clusters of thunderstorms developed across southwest, and west central Minnesota, and moved southeast along a strengthening gradient of instability and wind shear. There were numerous reports of large hail as a complex of storms began to organize, with hail stones measured up to 2.5 inches in diameter from a swath across southern Kandiyohi, western Renville, southwest McLeod, and parts of northwest, and central Sibley County. ||This hail storm was very significant in terms of crop damage as the swath of hail was up to 60 miles long and six miles wide. This affected thousands of acres of corn, soy beans, kidney beans, sugar beets, peas, sweet corn, and alfalfa. Acres upon acres were impacted and millions of dollars were lost. The University of Minnesota Extension looked into the damage and indicated the extent of damage to corn stalk and soybean farms was critical due to the time of year. The worst areas were in Renville, McLeod and Sibley Counties of south central Minnesota.||The storm shifted from a large hail event, to a wind event as a bow echo developed across Nicollet County and moved southeast quickly over portions of south central Minnesota. The most intense part of the storm early was northwest of Mankato, where a tornado touched down and uprooted trees and tore part of a roof off a machine shed. The bow echo continued to produce wind damage southeast across Blue Earth, and portions of Le Sueur Counties.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS station SD547, three miles southeast of Montrose, measured a peak wind gust of 58 mph.
episode_narrative: A mid-level disturbance moving from Wyoming into South Dakota initiated late evening convection in an environment with around 2000 J/kg MLCAPE and deep-layer shear of around 50 knots.  Storms expanded and rapidly evolved into a large-scale bow echo.

event_narrative: The ASOS at the University of Illinois Willard Airport measured a thunderstorm wind gust of 60 mph. No damage was reported.
episode_narrative: Strong thunderstorms developed along a stationary front in central and east central Illinois during the late afternoon of September 8th. One of the thunderstorms produced a measured 60 mph wind gust at the University of Illinois Willard Airport near Savoy Illinois shortly after 3:30 pm CDT. No damage was reported.

Scattered thunderstorms impacted the combined Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles. Many of these storms were initiated along outflow boundaries produced by storms that developed during the peak heating of the afternoon. Moisture was plentiful in the lower levels of the atmosphere with just enough instability for some of these storms to produce wind gusts up to and exceeding 60 mph along with penny to quarter size hail.

event_narrative: US Air Force wind tower 0311 measured a peak wind gust of 61 mph from the southwest.
episode_narrative: Numerous thunderstorms developed along outflow boundary and sea breeze collisions. These storms produced two tornadoes in western Volusia County, including a rare August EF-2. In addition, other thunderstorms produced strong winds and hail along the Volusia and Brevard County coasts.

event_narrative: The AWOS at the DeLand Municipal Airport, KDED, measured a peak wind gust of 73 mph from the south-southwest. Three prop planes at the airport were flipped, and several hangers sustained damage. Additionally, several medium sized trees were toppled and roof awnings destroyed in the Meadowlea Village, near Carter Road just north of the DeLand Airport.
episode_narrative: A thunderstorm became severe as it moved north through DeLand where it caused damage to planes and hangers at the airport, as well as nearby homes.

event_narrative: The ASOS at the Orlando-Sanford International Airport, KSFB, measured a peak wind gust of 59 mph from the west.
episode_narrative: A cluster of thunderstorms merged and became severe in Seminole County where several strong wind gusts were measured and damage to trees reported.

event_narrative: An amateur radio operator measured a peak wind gust of 62 mph on a personal weather station near the intersection of Lake Mary Boulevard and State Road 46.
episode_narrative: A cluster of thunderstorms merged and became severe in Seminole County where several strong wind gusts were measured and damage to trees reported.

Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that moved through Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties along the Kansas and Nebraska border. The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.

The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.

event_narrative: Wray AWOS observed a 58 mph wind gusts associated with a strong line of thunderstorms.
episode_narrative: Storms developed along the dry line in central Colorado increasing in coverage as they moved east. The cells merged into clusters along a line as they entered the area producing quarter sized hail and up to 64 mph wind gusts in eastern Colorado.

Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensified as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to ping pong ball sized hail, up to 93 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.5 inches of rain. During the event, several power poles were reported down in Cheyenne, Logan, Thomas, and Graham counties. Five oil tank batteries in Graham County and a central pivot irrigation system in Thomas County were also damaged.

event_narrative: KOLS ASOS at Nogales Airport recorded a wind gust to 59 mph.
episode_narrative: Scattered thunderstorms developed over Santa Cruz and southwest Cochise County during the afternoon and moved southwest through the evening. Storms produced heavy rain and large hail in the Elgin/Sonoita area and one storm uprooted trees at Tubac Presidio State Historic Park.

event_narrative: Personal weather station KSDMITCH21 measured a peak wind gust of 72 mph.
episode_narrative: Storms developing along a nearly stationary frontal boundary through central South Dakota and Nebraska organized into a line by late evening.  The environment with extreme mid-level instability (greater than 9 degrees C/km) and 1200-1500 J/kg DCAPE helped to enhance damaging wind gusts across southeast South Dakota into northwest Iowa.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS station SD588 near Fort Randall Dam measured a peak wind gust of 61 mph.
episode_narrative: A cold front pushing across central South Dakota and Nebraska ignited severe storms overnight. With elevated instability of 1000-1500 J/kg and an increasing low-level jet, numerous storms formed along the 700 hPa baroclinic zone with a few taking on bowing characteristics.

event_narrative: A personal weather station measured a wind gust to 74 mph.
episode_narrative: A few thunderstorms developed along a cold front approaching Interstate 29 in the late afternoon, with MLCAPE of 1500-2000 J/kg.  Storms quickly become outflow dominant and produced damaging wind.

event_narrative: Automated weather station KHON recorded a wind gust to 62 mph.
episode_narrative: A weak disturbance moving across South Dakota during the evening hours July 2 ignited thunderstorms which quickly became linear in structure, and featured damaging winds into the early overnight July 3.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS Station SD554 at the Platte-Winner bridge measured a wind gust to 65 mph.
episode_narrative: A weak disturbance moving across South Dakota during the evening hours July 2 ignited thunderstorms which quickly became linear in structure, and featured damaging winds into the early overnight July 3.

event_narrative: Personal weather station measured a wind gust to 59 mph.
episode_narrative: A weak disturbance moving across South Dakota during the evening hours July 2 ignited thunderstorms which quickly became linear in structure, and featured damaging winds into the early overnight July 3.

event_narrative: Wind gust to 62 mph measured by a personal weather station.
episode_narrative: A weak disturbance moving across South Dakota during the evening hours July 2 ignited thunderstorms which quickly became linear in structure, and featured damaging winds into the early overnight July 3.

event_narrative: Automated weather station KMHE measured a wind gust to 62 mph.
episode_narrative: A weak disturbance moving across South Dakota during the evening hours July 2 ignited thunderstorms which quickly became linear in structure, and featured damaging winds into the early overnight July 3.

event_narrative: Automated weather station KSUX near Sergeant Bluff measured a peak wind of 58 mph.
episode_narrative: A cold front pushing across central South Dakota and Nebraska ignited severe storms overnight. With elevated instability of 1000-1500 J/kg and an increasing low-level jet, numerous storms formed along the 700 hPa baroclinic zone with a few taking on bowing characteristics.

event_narrative: Automated weather station KSUX near Sergeant Bluff measured a secondary peak wind of 67 mph.
episode_narrative: A cold front pushing across central South Dakota and Nebraska ignited severe storms overnight. With elevated instability of 1000-1500 J/kg and an increasing low-level jet, numerous storms formed along the 700 hPa baroclinic zone with a few taking on bowing characteristics.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS station SD582, 3 miles north northwest of Wolsey, measured a peak wind gust of 61 mph.
episode_narrative: A mid-level disturbance moving from Wyoming into South Dakota initiated late evening convection in an environment with around 2000 J/kg MLCAPE and deep-layer shear of around 50 knots.  Storms expanded and rapidly evolved into a large-scale bow echo.

event_narrative: Mansfield Airport ASOS recorded a peak wind gust of 60 mph from a thunderstorm.
episode_narrative: On Sunday, November 15th, a very potent surface low moved northeast across the Great Lakes region. A cold front initially over Indiana produced a line of isolated to scattered showers, which quickly congealed into a fully developed line of thunderstorms as it progressed eastward toward and then through northern Ohio. The result was widespread, damaging wind gusts with the line of thunderstorms, and for several hours after the thunderstorms' passage. The strong surface wind gusts in the wake of the thunderstorms were the result of a tight surface pressure gradient and rapid surface pressure rises behind the cold front. Observed gusts of 60 mph+ were common. Damage was widespread to trees, power poles, roofs, and other miscellaneous items. There were also widespread power outages, with over 150k people losing power for a time.

A combination of an upper level trough moving northwest across the state, coupled with a strong surface pressure gradient, led to numerous reports of high wind gusts across  the region.  Most of the wind damage occurred with the passage of a rare derecho; a large fast-moving complex of thunderstorms with powerful straight-line winds.  In addition, strong wind gusts from 59 to 71 mph not associated with the derecho, occurred prior to and following the passage of this system over the urban corridor and plains of northeast Colorado.||By midday the derecho, which originated over the Great Basin, moved over the northern and central mountains, and then rapidly northeast across the I-25 corridor by mid afternoon.  These storms then tracked across the plains from late afternoon into the early evening hours.  Wind gusts from 60 to 80 mph were common with a few gusts exceeding 90 mph.  The highest gust observed was 110 mph, at the Winter Park Ski area, around 12000 feet.  Xcel Energy said in a press release that more than 208,000 customers lost power because of the storm statewide. The intense wind toppled a billboard that crashed onto Denver bakery.  Two delivery trucks parked nearby were heavily damaged.  Two injuries occurred in Denver, one seriously.  A man and his nine-year-old daughter were injured by a fallen tree.  They were standing in front of a family member���s house when the incident occurred.  The tree impaled the father through his back and he required several surgeries.  His daughter sustained cuts and bruises that required stitches.

Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that moved through Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties along the Kansas and Nebraska border. The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.

event_narrative: Law enforcement reported tree limbs of various sizes down along with a snapped power pole in northern McCook. The damage occurred near the time of a measured 79 mph wind gust at the McCook ASOS station.
episode_narrative: Storms developed along the dry line in central Colorado increasing in coverage as they moved east. The cells merged into clusters along a line as they entered southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas. The storms produced up to 79 mph wind gusts in Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties. The 79 mph gust in Red Willow County caused snapped a power pole and downed various sized of tree limbs.

event_narrative: Thunderstorm winds downed tree limbs that fell on and damaged a carport in Huachuca City. The residence also sustained minor roof and siding damage.
episode_narrative: Scattered thunderstorms developed and moved west-southwest across southeast Arizona during the late afternoon and early evening. Storms produced wind damage in the northwest Tucson Metro, Sells and Huachuca City. The winds also led to the development of a dust storm in Pinal County.

event_narrative: Guthrie RAWS station, on a 6300 foot peak, recorded a thunderstorm wind gust of 71 mph.
episode_narrative: Scattered thunderstorms developed and moved northeast across southeast Arizona during the afternoon and evening. One storm produced wind damage at Marana High School and another produced flash flooding over the Bighorn Fire burn scar.
An isolated thunderstorm over Logan County produced intense microburst wind gusts near Iliff and Crook.  No damage was reported.

A strong storm system moved across the area the afternoon of the 8th into the morning of the 9th.  This system produced severe thunderstorms and high winds, across northeast Colorado, with snow across the mountains, valley areas and higher foothills.  In addition rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches occurred across the plains.   Storm totals included:  15 inches, 9 miles south-southeast of Gould and 7 miles northwest of Red Feather Lakes; 11 inches near Cameron Pass; with 4 to 10 inches elsewhere.  Strong northwest winds developed across the northeast plains on the evening of the 8th into the early morning hours of the 9th, with peak gusts from 58 to 71 mph.  ||Severe thunderstorms  on the evening of the 8th, produced powerful and destructive wind gusts along with nickel to quarter size hail, over portions of northeast Colorado.  Peak wind gusts up to 80 mph occurred, with localized gusts from 100 to 113 mph, in and near Akron.  The swath of damaging winds extended from central Washington County into Logan County and across western areas of Phillips and Sedgwick counties.  Widespread crop and property damage was observed.

event_narrative: Trained spotter observed several live tree limbs down with the largest measuring 4 inches in diameter. 50 mph wind speed based off recorded gust at time from the Norton AWOS.
episode_narrative: Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensified as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to ping pong ball sized hail, up to 93 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.5 inches of rain. During the event, several power poles were reported down in Cheyenne, Logan, Thomas, and Graham counties. Five oil tank batteries in Graham County and a central pivot irrigation system in Thomas County were also damaged.

event_narrative: Law enforcement reported numerous live tree limbs and power lines down causing power outages. Four tank batteries for oil were blown over and an additional oil battery south of Hill City caught on fire. A power pole was also knocked down. The Hill City ASOS observed a 93 mph wind gust at the time the damage occurred.

event_narrative: Mesonet station reported a wind gust of 80 mph at location at start time. Public report received at end time of tree blown down and car window broken due to thunderstorm wind gust at location.
episode_narrative: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front moving eastward through northwestern Kansas. Thunderstorms produced strong wind gusts including a downburst event near St. Francis, KS producing damaging wind gusts up to 81 mph.

episode_narrative: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front moving eastward through northwestern Kansas. Thunderstorms produced strong wind gusts including a downburst event near St. Francis, KS producing damaging wind gusts up to 81 mph.

event_narrative: KNRN AWOS reported a 58 mph wind gust at location.
episode_narrative: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front moving eastward through northwestern Kansas. Thunderstorms produced strong wind gusts including a downburst event near St. Francis, KS producing damaging wind gusts up to 81 mph.

event_narrative: Automated weather station K9V9 measured a peak wind gust of 67 mph.
episode_narrative: Storms developing along a nearly stationary frontal boundary through central South Dakota and Nebraska organized into a line by late evening.  The environment with extreme mid-level instability (greater than 9 degrees C/km) and 1200-1500 J/kg DCAPE helped to enhance damaging wind gusts across southeast South Dakota into northwest Iowa.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS site SD537 measured a peak wind gust of 58 mph.
episode_narrative: Storms developing along a nearly stationary frontal boundary through central South Dakota and Nebraska organized into a line by late evening.  The environment with extreme mid-level instability (greater than 9 degrees C/km) and 1200-1500 J/kg DCAPE helped to enhance damaging wind gusts across southeast South Dakota into northwest Iowa.

event_narrative: A wind gust to 60 mph was recorded on a personal weather station.
episode_narrative: Weak shear and marginal instability, battling a fairly strong cap, meant mainly elevated and sporadic storm development in southeast South Dakota during the afternoon and evening hours.

event_narrative: Automated weather station KHON near Huron, SD measured a peak wind gust of 84 mph.
episode_narrative: A mid-level disturbance moving from Wyoming into South Dakota initiated late evening convection in an environment with around 2000 J/kg MLCAPE and deep-layer shear of around 50 knots.  Storms expanded and rapidly evolved into a large-scale bow echo.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS station SD515, three miles east of Cavour, measured a peak wind gust of 75 mph.
episode_narrative: A mid-level disturbance moving from Wyoming into South Dakota initiated late evening convection in an environment with around 2000 J/kg MLCAPE and deep-layer shear of around 50 knots.  Storms expanded and rapidly evolved into a large-scale bow echo.

event_narrative: KNRN AWOS reported a 64 mph thunderstorm wind gust.
episode_narrative: Clusters of thunderstorms developed in northwestern Kansas during the afternoon and evening hours of July 29th. These thunderstorms produced hail up to half dollar size along with damaging wind gusts up to 65 mph.

event_narrative: Mesonet station reported a 59 mph thunderstorm wind gust at location.
episode_narrative: Clusters of thunderstorms developed in northwestern Kansas during the afternoon and evening hours of July 29th. These thunderstorms produced hail up to half dollar size along with damaging wind gusts up to 65 mph.

A combination of an upper level trough moving northwest across the state, coupled with a strong surface pressure gradient, led to numerous reports of high wind gusts across  the region.  Most of the wind damage occurred with the passage of a rare derecho; a large fast-moving complex of thunderstorms with powerful straight-line winds.  In addition, strong wind gusts from 59 to 71 mph not associated with the derecho, occurred prior to and following the passage of this system over the urban corridor and plains of northeast Colorado.||By midday the derecho, which originated over the Great Basin, moved over the northern and central mountains, and then rapidly northeast across the I-25 corridor by mid afternoon.  These storms then tracked across the plains from late afternoon into the early evening hours.  Wind gusts from 60 to 80 mph were common with a few gusts exceeding 90 mph.  The highest gust observed was 110 mph, at the Winter Park Ski area, around 12000 feet.  Xcel Energy said in a press release that more than 208,000 customers lost power because of the storm statewide. The intense wind toppled a billboard that crashed onto Denver bakery.  Two delivery trucks parked nearby were heavily damaged.  Two injuries occurred in Denver, one seriously.  A man and his nine-year-old daughter were injured by a fallen tree.  They were standing in front of a family member���s house when the incident occurred.  The tree impaled the father through his back and he required several surgeries.  His daughter sustained cuts and bruises that required stitches.

The tree impaled the father through his back and he required several surgeries.  His daughter sustained cuts and bruises that required stitches.

event_narrative: Personal weather station measured a 60 mph wind gust.
episode_narrative: A strong line of storms developed near south central South Dakota and tracked southeast producing wind damage with gusts over 60 mph in Madison, Stanton, and Cuming counties.

event_narrative: Mesonet station CW6099 measured a 59 mph wind gust associated with thunderstorm outflow.
episode_narrative: Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensified as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to ping pong ball sized hail, up to 93 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.5 inches of rain. During the event, several power poles were reported down in Cheyenne, Logan, Thomas, and Graham counties. Five oil tank batteries in Graham County and a central pivot irrigation system in Thomas County were also damaged.

event_narrative: Mesonet measured a 62 mph wind gusts.

event_narrative: Thunderstorm wind gust to 65 mph measured by hand-held anemometer.
episode_narrative: Storms developing along a nearly stationary frontal boundary through central South Dakota and Nebraska organized into a line by late evening.  The environment with extreme mid-level instability (greater than 9 degrees C/km) and 1200-1500 J/kg DCAPE helped to enhance damaging wind gusts across southeast South Dakota into northwest Iowa.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS station SD554 14 miles west of Platte near the Platte-Winner bridge measured a peak wind gust of 72 mph.
episode_narrative: Lift associated with a jet streak across southern North Dakota interacted with an unstable and weakly capped environment with 30 to 40 knots of deep-layer shear to produce a couple of smaller clusters of thunderstorms with large hail and damaging wind during the evening and overnight which progressed east and southeast across southeast South Dakota.  The final cluster was a larger-scale bowing segment which produced damaging wind gusts across south central South Dakota.  Repeated storms with heavy rainfall resulted in spotty flash flooding.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS station SD588 near Fort Randall Dam measured a peak wind gust of 64 mph.
episode_narrative: Lift associated with a jet streak across southern North Dakota interacted with an unstable and weakly capped environment with 30 to 40 knots of deep-layer shear to produce a couple of smaller clusters of thunderstorms with large hail and damaging wind during the evening and overnight which progressed east and southeast across southeast South Dakota.  The final cluster was a larger-scale bowing segment which produced damaging wind gusts across south central South Dakota.  Repeated storms with heavy rainfall resulted in spotty flash flooding.

A round of severe thunderstorms moved west to east across south central and southeast Kansas in the evening hours of November 24th. There were reports of 60 mph winds in multiple locations as well as quarter to ping pong ball sized hail in few spots.

event_narrative: AccuWeather meteorologist measured 59 mph at the intersection of Central and West streets.
episode_narrative: A round of severe thunderstorms moved west to east across south central and southeast Kansas in the evening hours of November 24th. There were reports of 60 mph winds in multiple locations as well as quarter to ping pong ball sized hail in few spots.

event_narrative: Measured at High Point Monument.
episode_narrative: A strong cold front along with a mid-level shortwave trough approached the mid-Atlantic on August 25. Ahead of the disturbances, wind shear increased significantly and surface temperatures warmed, increasing instability. While some ingredients were in place for a major severe weather event, an offset in timing between the shortwave and the front, combined with greater than expected mid-level dry air, caused storms to generally struggle to develop over the mid-Atlantic. Greater storm coverage was found in more favorable environments over both New England and the Ohio Valley. However, the environment over the mid-Atlantic was still highly favorable for damaging winds, so the few storms that did develop produced some instances of wind damage.

event_narrative: A USDA Agricultural Research Station meteorological tower measured a wind gust of 0.54 m/s, or 113 mph, from the west. Pine trees nearby were snapped and blown on to County Road GG immediately north of US 34.
episode_narrative: A strong storm system moved across the area the afternoon of the 8th into the morning of the 9th.  This system produced severe thunderstorms and high winds, across northeast Colorado, with snow across the mountains, valley areas and higher foothills.  In addition rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches occurred across the plains.   Storm totals included:  15 inches, 9 miles south-southeast of Gould and 7 miles northwest of Red Feather Lakes; 11 inches near Cameron Pass; with 4 to 10 inches elsewhere.  Strong northwest winds developed across the northeast plains on the evening of the 8th into the early morning hours of the 9th, with peak gusts from 58 to 71 mph.  ||Severe thunderstorms  on the evening of the 8th, produced powerful and destructive wind gusts along with nickel to quarter size hail, over portions of northeast Colorado.  Peak wind gusts up to 80 mph occurred, with localized gusts from 100 to 113 mph, in and near Akron.  The swath of damaging winds extended from central Washington County into Logan County and across western areas of Phillips and Sedgwick counties.  Widespread crop and property damage was observed.

Storms developed along the dry line in central Colorado increasing in coverage as they moved east. The cells merged into clusters along a line as they entered southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas. The storms produced up to 79 mph wind gusts in Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties. The 79 mph gust in Red Willow County caused snapped a power pole and downed various sized of tree limbs.

event_narrative: A thunderstorm wind gust of 58 mph was recorded by K2V6 AWOS at location.
episode_narrative: Thunderstorms developed during the evening hours in eastern Colorado due to an upper air disturbance. These thunderstorms yielded winds up to 59 mph that damaged property. As the showers and storms diminished in the early hours of the next day, a wind gust of 58 mph associated with a heat burst was recorded.

episode_narrative: Scattered thunderstorms developed and moved west-southwest across southeast Arizona during the late afternoon and early evening. Storms produced wind damage in the northwest Tucson Metro, Sells and Huachuca City. The winds also led to the development of a dust storm in Pinal County.

event_narrative: Thunderstorm winds downed several trees in Catalina.

A man and his nine-year-old daughter were injured by a fallen tree.  They were standing in front of a family member���s house when the incident occurred.  The tree impaled the father through his back and he required several surgeries.  His daughter sustained cuts and bruises that required stitches.

A strong storm system moved across the area the afternoon of the 8th into the morning of the 9th.  This system produced severe thunderstorms and high winds, across northeast Colorado, with snow across the mountains, valley areas and higher foothills.  In addition rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches occurred across the plains.   Storm totals included:  15 inches, 9 miles south-southeast of Gould and 7 miles northwest of Red Feather Lakes; 11 inches near Cameron Pass; with 4 to 10 inches elsewhere.  Strong northwest winds developed across the northeast plains on the evening of the 8th into the early morning hours of the 9th, with peak gusts from 58 to 71 mph.  ||Severe thunderstorms  on the evening of the 8th, produced powerful and destructive wind gusts along with nickel to quarter size hail, over portions of northeast Colorado.  Peak wind gusts up to 80 mph occurred, with localized gusts from 100 to 113 mph, in and near Akron.  The swath of damaging winds extended from central Washington County into Logan County and across western areas of Phillips and Sedgwick counties.  Widespread crop and property damage was observed.

event_narrative: Personal weather station EW7290 near Fairfax measured a peak wind gust of 73 mph.
episode_narrative: A cold front pushing across central South Dakota and Nebraska ignited severe storms overnight. With elevated instability of 1000-1500 J/kg and an increasing low-level jet, numerous storms formed along the 700 hPa baroclinic zone with a few taking on bowing characteristics.
A line of thunderstorms crossed much of northwest and central Oklahoma during the evening of the 13th, with numerous reports of severe winds received.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS station SD553 measured a wind gust to 58 mph.
episode_narrative: Weak shear and marginal instability, battling a fairly strong cap, meant mainly elevated and sporadic storm development in southeast South Dakota during the afternoon and evening hours.

event_narrative: Winds to 60 mph were measured by a personal weather station.
episode_narrative: Lift associated with a jet streak across southern North Dakota interacted with an unstable and weakly capped environment with 30 to 40 knots of deep-layer shear to produce a couple of smaller clusters of thunderstorms with large hail and damaging wind during the evening and overnight which progressed east and southeast across southeast South Dakota.  The final cluster was a larger-scale bowing segment which produced damaging wind gusts across south central South Dakota.  Repeated storms with heavy rainfall resulted in spotty flash flooding.

During the evening of Friday, July 17th, a line of strong to severe thunderstorms that developed across northwest Minnesota, propagated south-southeast across central Minnesota and became a well defined bow echo segment. There were two areas that had the worst damage. One occurred in Stevens County where a swath of wind damage extended 3/4 of a mile to the southeast of Chokio, and about 1/4 of a mile wide. Many trees were snapped off just above the base, while others were uprooted. The second area was associated with straight-line winds, occasional downbursts, and two tornadoes that hit northern Isanti, and northern Chisago Counties. ||There was ample instability and wind shear during the evening to hold supercell characteristics along this bow echo segment. As the storm bowed out to the southeast late in the evening, less instability and wind shear diminished the organized nature of the bow segment. However, a one bow echo segment allowed for two tornadic storms near Day and Rush City.  ||There was continued weakening of this bow echo overnight, with more individual line segments which caused brief, and isolated wind damage. Even local airport wind sensors, and private wind sensors were measuring wind gusts in the 40 to 50 mph range past midnight LST. The exception was in the Twin Cities metro area where the Flying Cloud airport measured a wind gust of 59 mph, and the Minneapolis/St. Paul airport measured a wind gust of 55 mph.

A 50 to 55 knot low level jet was moving across western New York during the morning hours as a pre-frontal surface trough was moving through. A 30-40 mile wide swath of steady light rain preceded the surface feature. While there were no visible convective elements within the swath of rain, there was embedded convection just prior to the rain moving through, and there was impressive elevated instability present. The rain temporarily stabilized the air mass to the point where the stronger winds from aloft could not mix to the surface, but as the rain tapered off, winds quickly ramped up with gusts of 40-50 mph. Initial wind gusts over Niagara County were as expected, however just as the rain ended further to the south and east, gusts of 55-60 mph were experienced with damage. The convectively-enhanced winds brought down some trees and caused power outages, mainly across the Genesee Valley and especially the Southern Tier. The radar did show a wavy line of showers moving through the Genesee valley at the time of the highest winds, with the damaging winds coming immediately in the wake of the steady rain across the Southern Tier. This was likely convectively-enhanced wind damage given its proximity to the wavy line of showers and also because winds quickly dropped back to gusts of 30-35 mph.

event_narrative: Measured by NJWeathenet site NJ67.
episode_narrative: A strong cold front along with a mid-level shortwave trough approached the mid-Atlantic on August 25. Ahead of the disturbances, wind shear increased significantly and surface temperatures warmed, increasing instability. While some ingredients were in place for a major severe weather event, an offset in timing between the shortwave and the front, combined with greater than expected mid-level dry air, caused storms to generally struggle to develop over the mid-Atlantic. Greater storm coverage was found in more favorable environments over both New England and the Ohio Valley. However, the environment over the mid-Atlantic was still highly favorable for damaging winds, so the few storms that did develop produced some instances of wind damage.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS station SD588 near Fort Randall Dam measured a wind gust to 68 mph.
episode_narrative: A potent environment with 2500-3000 J/kg MLCAPE remained weakly capped until a wave moved across northern Nebraska by mid to late evening.  Clusters of thunderstorms developed and organized into short bowing segments, which produced spotty damaging wind gusts.

event_narrative: ASOS station KGLD measured a 61 mph wind gust from the core of a thunderstorm passing over the site.
episode_narrative: Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensified as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to ping pong ball sized hail, up to 93 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.5 inches of rain. During the event, several power poles were reported down in Cheyenne, Logan, Thomas, and Graham counties. Five oil tank batteries in Graham County and a central pivot irrigation system in Thomas County were also damaged.

event_narrative: A trained spotter measured a 62 mph wind gust.
episode_narrative: A severe quasi-linear convective system (QLCS) moved through southeast Georgia during the early morning hours of April 13, 2020 ahead of an approaching cold front. The environment ahead of the QLCS was unusually unstable for this time of day and year, with gulf moisture spreading upper 60 F to near 70 F dewpoints into a warm sector across the Southeast United States and mid level lapse rates around 7 C/km helping produce mixed layer convective available potential energy (MLCAPE) as high as 2000 J/kg across Southeast Georgia. Within the warm sector, very strong vertical shear associated with a 50 knot plus low and mid-level jet, effective bulk shear around 70 knots, effective storm relative helicity in the 400-600 m2/s2 range, and VAD wind profiles displaying large, curved low-level hodographs were supportive of well organized convection and potentially embedded supercell thunderstorms in a QLCS capable of producing a prolonged path of damaging winds and strong long-track tornadoes. As the QLCS swept through Southeast Georgia, a few thunderstorms became exceptionally strong supercell thunderstorms embedded within or while becoming partially separated from the main line of thunderstorms, producing straight-line wind damage and a series of tornadoes across a few counties. A total of 4 confirmed tornadoes occurred across Southeast Georgia, mainly from 2 long-lived storms, one of which started in Screven County and continued northeast into South Carolina, producing widespread wind damage and destructive long track or intermittent tornadoes for over 150 miles. The second storm, produced a path of straight-line wind damage and intermittent tornadoes along a path further south, starting outside the area across Wayne County, then tracking east-northeast into Long County and continuing across Liberty County and Bryant County, before shifting offshore along the Southeast Georgia coast.

Most of the wind damage occurred with the passage of a rare derecho; a large fast-moving complex of thunderstorms with powerful straight-line winds.  In addition, strong wind gusts from 59 to 71 mph not associated with the derecho, occurred prior to and following the passage of this system over the urban corridor and plains of northeast Colorado.||By midday the derecho, which originated over the Great Basin, moved over the northern and central mountains, and then rapidly northeast across the I-25 corridor by mid afternoon.  These storms then tracked across the plains from late afternoon into the early evening hours.  Wind gusts from 60 to 80 mph were common with a few gusts exceeding 90 mph.  The highest gust observed was 110 mph, at the Winter Park Ski area, around 12000 feet.  Xcel Energy said in a press release that more than 208,000 customers lost power because of the storm statewide. The intense wind toppled a billboard that crashed onto Denver bakery.  Two delivery trucks parked nearby were heavily damaged.  Two injuries occurred in Denver, one seriously.  A man and his nine-year-old daughter were injured by a fallen tree.  They were standing in front of a family member���s house when the incident occurred.  The tree impaled the father through his back and he required several surgeries.  His daughter sustained cuts and bruises that required stitches.

Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that developed into a line as it moved through northwest Kansas. The storms produced up to golf ball sized hail and wind gusts near 70 mph that produced brown out conditions and snapped numerous tree limbs in Logan, Thomas, Gove, and Sheridan counties.

event_narrative: CWOP AU921 south of Bowie measured a thunderstorm wind gust to 59 mph.
episode_narrative: Scattered thunderstorms developed over the Mogollon Rim during the afternoon and moved south-southwest into Cochise County during the evening.  One storm produced a severe wind gust near Bowie.

During the late morning of Saturday, July 11th, several clusters of thunderstorms developed across southwest, and west central Minnesota, and moved southeast along a strengthening gradient of instability and wind shear. There were numerous reports of large hail as a complex of storms began to organize, with hail stones measured up to 2.5 inches in diameter from a swath across southern Kandiyohi, western Renville, southwest McLeod, and parts of northwest, and central Sibley County. ||This hail storm was very significant in terms of crop damage as the swath of hail was up to 60 miles long and six miles wide. This affected thousands of acres of corn, soy beans, kidney beans, sugar beets, peas, sweet corn, and alfalfa. Acres upon acres were impacted and millions of dollars were lost. The University of Minnesota Extension looked into the damage and indicated the extent of damage to corn stalk and soybean farms was critical due to the time of year. The worst areas were in Renville, McLeod and Sibley Counties of south central Minnesota.||The storm shifted from a large hail event, to a wind event as a bow echo developed across Nicollet County and moved southeast quickly over portions of south central Minnesota. The most intense part of the storm early was northwest of Mankato, where a tornado touched down and uprooted trees and tore part of a roof off a machine shed. The bow echo continued to produce wind damage southeast across Blue Earth, and portions of Le Sueur Counties.
An isolated thunderstorm over Logan County produced intense microburst wind gusts near Iliff and Crook.  No damage was reported.

A strong storm system moved across the area the afternoon of the 8th into the morning of the 9th.  This system produced severe thunderstorms and high winds, across northeast Colorado, with snow across the mountains, valley areas and higher foothills.  In addition rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches occurred across the plains.   Storm totals included:  15 inches, 9 miles south-southeast of Gould and 7 miles northwest of Red Feather Lakes; 11 inches near Cameron Pass; with 4 to 10 inches elsewhere.  Strong northwest winds developed across the northeast plains on the evening of the 8th into the early morning hours of the 9th, with peak gusts from 58 to 71 mph.  ||Severe thunderstorms  on the evening of the 8th, produced powerful and destructive wind gusts along with nickel to quarter size hail, over portions of northeast Colorado.  Peak wind gusts up to 80 mph occurred, with localized gusts from 100 to 113 mph, in and near Akron.  The swath of damaging winds extended from central Washington County into Logan County and across western areas of Phillips and Sedgwick counties.  Widespread crop and property damage was observed.

Storms developed along the dry line in central Colorado increasing in coverage as they moved east. The cells merged into clusters along a line as they entered southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas The storms produced up to golf ball sized hail, up to 70 mph wind gusts, and up to 3 inches of rain.

event_narrative: Live tree 1 foot in diameter and 25 feet long knocked down by winds measured a few miles east at 65 mph.

The cells merged into clusters along a line as they entered southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas The storms produced up to golf ball sized hail, up to 70 mph wind gusts, and up to 3 inches of rain.

event_narrative: Automated weather station KAGZ near Wagner measured a peak wind gust of 61 mph.
episode_narrative: A cold front pushing across central South Dakota and Nebraska ignited severe storms overnight. With elevated instability of 1000-1500 J/kg and an increasing low-level jet, numerous storms formed along the 700 hPa baroclinic zone with a few taking on bowing characteristics.

event_narrative: A measured wind report of 53 knots from a private weather station.
episode_narrative: During the evening of Friday, July 17th, a line of strong to severe thunderstorms that developed across northwest Minnesota, propagated south-southeast across central Minnesota and became a well defined bow echo segment. There were two areas that had the worst damage. One occurred in Stevens County where a swath of wind damage extended 3/4 of a mile to the southeast of Chokio, and about 1/4 of a mile wide. Many trees were snapped off just above the base, while others were uprooted. The second area was associated with straight-line winds, occasional downbursts, and two tornadoes that hit northern Isanti, and northern Chisago Counties. ||There was ample instability and wind shear during the evening to hold supercell characteristics along this bow echo segment. As the storm bowed out to the southeast late in the evening, less instability and wind shear diminished the organized nature of the bow segment. However, a one bow echo segment allowed for two tornadic storms near Day and Rush City.  ||There was continued weakening of this bow echo overnight, with more individual line segments which caused brief, and isolated wind damage. Even local airport wind sensors, and private wind sensors were measuring wind gusts in the 40 to 50 mph range past midnight LST. The exception was in the Twin Cities metro area where the Flying Cloud airport measured a wind gust of 59 mph, and the Minneapolis/St. Paul airport measured a wind gust of 55 mph.

event_narrative: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced wind gusts to 58 mph at the Ford Airport ASOS in Iron Mountain on the evening of the 23rd.
episode_narrative: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced wind gusts to 58 mph at the Ford Airport ASOS in Iron Mountain on the evening of the 23rd.

event_narrative: A strong wind gust was reported by broadcast media.
episode_narrative: A cluster of strong to severe thunderstorms brought some damaging winds and very heavy rain to much of eastern and northeastern Iowa, and northwest Illinois during the late evening of September 5 into the early morning of September 6.

event_narrative: A strong wind gust was reported by broadcast media.

event_narrative: Reported at the Davenport Airport.

event_narrative: Peak wind gust of 59 mph recorded at Akron Fulton Int'l Airport ASOS during thunderstorm.
episode_narrative: On Sunday, November 15th, a very potent surface low moved northeast across the Great Lakes region. A cold front initially over Indiana produced a line of isolated to scattered showers, which quickly congealed into a fully developed line of thunderstorms as it progressed eastward toward and then through northern Ohio. The result was widespread, damaging wind gusts with the line of thunderstorms, and for several hours after the thunderstorms' passage. The strong surface wind gusts in the wake of the thunderstorms were the result of a tight surface pressure gradient and rapid surface pressure rises behind the cold front. Observed gusts of 60 mph+ were common. Damage was widespread to trees, power poles, roofs, and other miscellaneous items. There were also widespread power outages, with over 150k people losing power for a time.

event_narrative: Peak wind gust of 63 mph recorded at the Akron-Canton Regional Airport ASOS during thunderstorm.

event_narrative: The Valley City mesonet station, located five miles southwest of Brunswick, recorded a peak wind gust of 76 mph from a thunderstorm.
episode_narrative: On Sunday, November 15th, a very potent surface low moved northeast across the Great Lakes region. A cold front initially over Indiana produced a line of isolated to scattered showers, which quickly congealed into a fully developed line of thunderstorms as it progressed eastward toward and then through northern Ohio. The result was widespread, damaging wind gusts with the line of thunderstorms, and for several hours after the thunderstorms' passage. The strong surface wind gusts in the wake of the thunderstorms were the result of a tight surface pressure gradient and rapid surface pressure rises behind the cold front. Observed gusts of 60 mph+ were common. Damage was widespread to trees, power poles, roofs, and other miscellaneous items. There were also widespread power outages, with over 150k people losing power for a time.

event_narrative: Personal weather station recorded a 72 mph peak wind gust from a thunderstorm.

event_narrative: Thunderstorm wind gusts were measured to 63 mph.
episode_narrative: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed across western and central Oklahoma during the afternoon of the 24th, along and ahead of an approaching cold front. The thunderstorms intensified as they moved eastward and across eastern Oklahoma during the late afternoon and evening hours. The strongest storms produced large hail up to golf ball size, damaging wind gusts, and two tornadoes.

A combination of an upper level trough moving northwest across the state, coupled with a strong surface pressure gradient, led to numerous reports of high wind gusts across  the region.  Most of the wind damage occurred with the passage of a rare derecho; a large fast-moving complex of thunderstorms with powerful straight-line winds.  In addition, strong wind gusts from 59 to 71 mph not associated with the derecho, occurred prior to and following the passage of this system over the urban corridor and plains of northeast Colorado.||By midday the derecho, which originated over the Great Basin, moved over the northern and central mountains, and then rapidly northeast across the I-25 corridor by mid afternoon.  These storms then tracked across the plains from late afternoon into the early evening hours.  Wind gusts from 60 to 80 mph were common with a few gusts exceeding 90 mph.  The highest gust observed was 110 mph, at the Winter Park Ski area, around 12000 feet.  Xcel Energy said in a press release that more than 208,000 customers lost power because of the storm statewide. The intense wind toppled a billboard that crashed onto Denver bakery.  Two delivery trucks parked nearby were heavily damaged.  Two injuries occurred in Denver, one seriously.  A man and his nine-year-old daughter were injured by a fallen tree.  They were standing in front of a family member���s house when the incident occurred.  The tree impaled the father through his back and he required several surgeries.  His daughter sustained cuts and bruises that required stitches.

event_narrative: ASOS station KITR at the Kit Carson County Airport measured a 61 mph wind gusts as a line of storms passed over the location.
episode_narrative: Discrete and clustered thunderstorms formed along and behind a SE-NW oriented boundary associated with an upper level disturbance moving east across eastern Colorado. As the boundary moved closer to the CO-KS border, the storms merged into a linear system extending from Kit Carson County north into Wyoming. To the south in Cheyenne County, a separate cluster of storms extended across the state line into Greeley County, KS. The storms produced up to ping pong sized hail in Cheyenne County and a 61 mph wind gust in Kit Carson County.

Storms developed along the dry line in central Colorado increasing in coverage as they moved east. The cells merged into clusters along a line as they entered the area producing quarter sized hail and up to 64 mph wind gusts in eastern Colorado.

Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensified as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to ping pong ball sized hail, up to 93 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.5 inches of rain. During the event, several power poles were reported down in Cheyenne, Logan, Thomas, and Graham counties. Five oil tank batteries in Graham County and a central pivot irrigation system in Thomas County were also damaged.

event_narrative: South Dakota RWIS gage SD571 measured a peak wind gust of 58 mph. Crop damage is an estimate from insured losses. Information provided by the United States Department of Agriculture.
episode_narrative: Storms developing along a nearly stationary frontal boundary through central South Dakota and Nebraska organized into a line by late evening.  The environment with extreme mid-level instability (greater than 9 degrees C/km) and 1200-1500 J/kg DCAPE helped to enhance damaging wind gusts across southeast South Dakota into northwest Iowa.

event_narrative: A 60 mph wind gust was reported at Clines Corners from the same thunderstorm that produced damaging winds in Albuquerque.
episode_narrative: The high pressure system responsible for several consecutive days of record high temperatures and dry conditions finally began to weaken and shift eastward toward the Texas Panhandle. This allowed mid-level moisture to stream into portions of western and central NM which resulted in scattered thunderstorms developing during the afternoon and evening hours on July 13, 2020. Storms initially formed over the western and northern high terrain early in the afternoon before moving eastward into valley locations. With drier low-levels, the main hazards with these storms was strong outflow winds. One severe storm in the Albuquerque metro area produced winds near 60 mph which reduced visibility and downed a few trees.

event_narrative: Iowa RWIS station RSCI4, 1 mile southwest of Moville, measured a peak wind gust of 58 mph. Crop damage is an estimate from insured losses. Information provided by the United States Department of Agriculture.
episode_narrative: A cold front pushing across central South Dakota and Nebraska ignited severe storms overnight. With elevated instability of 1000-1500 J/kg and an increasing low-level jet, numerous storms formed along the 700 hPa baroclinic zone with a few taking on bowing characteristics.

event_narrative: The AWOS at Jim Taylor Field measured a wind gust of 46 mph. This event was given minimal damage as it corresponds to a wind damage report in Ocala just prior to this wind speed measurement.
episode_narrative: A mid/upper level ridge was over the coastal Carolinas with Tropical Storm Sally tracking northward across the eastern Gulf of Mexico. Stronger easterly flow between these two system produced gusty gradient winds along the coast near 35-40 mph at times through the day. Inland thunderstorms formed over a moist and unstable environment over NE FL, with a few strong storms producing minor wind damage.

event_narrative: Measured at the Moline International Airport.
episode_narrative: Severe thunderstorms developed across eastern Iowa and northwest Illinois Saturday, July 11, producing widespread wind damage and very large hail. The first line of storms came through during the morning, producing damaging wind gusts and reports of quarter to ping pong ball size hail from Independence to Tipton Iowa. A wind gust of 65 MPH was measured just west of Independence. The second round of thunderstorms developed as a result of an upper level disturbance interacting with an atmosphere characterized by extremely high instability with modest vertical wind shear. Activity initially formed in north central Iowa, producing golf ball to two inch hail from Fort Dodge to Waterloo Iowa. Eventually, storms made their way towards the Cedar Rapids/Iowa City metro areas, producing widespread wind damage and hail up to baseball size. These storms continued through the Quad Cities metro east towards Princeton, Sterling, and Hennepin Illinois, producing additional reports of wind damage and winds of 70 to 90 mph. Numerous power outages were also reported.

event_narrative: A home weather station recorded an 84 mph wind gust.
episode_narrative: A cluster of intense thunderstorms moved across southeast Iowa and western Illinois in the morning hours of July 19th. This cluster of storms brought very heavy rain, and very strong damaging winds. Several locations saw winds over 75 mph, and had significant property damage.

event_narrative: The Crane Flat RAWS reported a peak thunderstorm wind gust of 59 mph.
episode_narrative: An extended period of hot temperatures took place over the region between June 23 and June 27. During the afternoon of June 25, there was enough instability over the Sierra Nevada range for scattered thunderstorms to break out. A few of the thunderstorms produced strong wind gusts in Yosemite National Park, and several trees that has been killed or weakened by a long term drought between 2013 and 2016 were blown over by the strong wind gusts.

event_narrative: The Weatherflow site on the north side of Rodanthe measured the gust.
episode_narrative: A strong cold front swept through Eastern NC late Christmas Eve. Periods of showers and thunderstorms accompanied the cold front, with several storms becoming severe. Strong southerly wind gusts of 60 to 70 mph and minor coastal flooding accompanied the front as well.

event_narrative: The Cape Hatteras ASOS measured the wind gust.
episode_narrative: A strong cold front swept through Eastern NC late Christmas Eve. Periods of showers and thunderstorms accompanied the cold front, with several storms becoming severe. Strong southerly wind gusts of 60 to 70 mph and minor coastal flooding accompanied the front as well.

event_narrative: Minnesota RWIS station MN030 3 miles south of Hendricks measured a peak wind gust of 70 mph.
episode_narrative: A strong jet streak moved across Montana and North Dakota during the afternoon and early evening, providing enough lift to overcome a lid of warmer temperatures aloft across central South Dakota. Storms progressed east and southeast and utilized drying within the elevated layer to generate enough cooling to produce hail, and environmental deep-layer shear of 45 to 55 knots to organize into short bowing segments.

event_narrative: Minnesota RWIS station MN038 3 miles west of Dovray measured a peak wind gust of 63 mph.

event_narrative: A peak wind gust of 58 mph was measured by the automated weather station at the Rifle Garfield County Airport.
episode_narrative: Midlevel moisture gradually increased across western Colorado as a ridge of high pressure remained overhead. This increase in moisture was enough to fuel scattered showers and thunderstorms on Sunday, July 12th and again on Monday, July 13th. However, the lower levels of the atmosphere remained dry which led to minimal rainfall and gusty and erratic outflow winds from showers and storms.

event_narrative: A wind gust of 65 MPH was measured by a Kansas Mesonet site located 3 miles west-northwest of Jewell.
episode_narrative: Arguably the most noteworthy individual thunderstorm of the 2020 convective season within this six-county North Central Kansas area rolled southward across portions of Jewell, Mitchell and mainly eastern Osborne counties on this Friday evening, highlighted by several reports of large to very large hail. Of the counties impacted by this supercell, Jewell was hardest-hit, as copious amounts of tennis ball to softball size hail stones crashed down onto areas in and near the communities of Mankato and Jewell, causing extensive damage to homes, vehicles and area crops. The hail size toned down somewhat farther south into Mitchell and Osborne counties, where limited reports included ping pong ball size stones in Cawker City and golf ball size south of Osborne. Although damaging winds were not a major player during this event, several mesonets clocked gusts of at least 40-50 MPH, and a Kansas Mesonet site near Jewell reached severe-criteria with 65 MPH. Flooding was not much of an issue, with convection staying progressive enough to keep rainfall amounts largely under one inch.||Breaking down event timing and meteorological background, this giant storm invaded northern Jewell County between 7-8 pm. CDT, having already propagated south-southwestward for roughly 90 miles since its inception in east central Nebraska about three hours prior. As it drifted southward into Mitchell County between 8-9 p.m. CDT it started merging with a much smaller, separate storm that had flared up over central Osborne County. Finally, between 9-10 p.m. CDT, the now-merged supercell cluster continued southward while exiting the local area into central Kansas, ending all local storms for the night. This was actually a fairly conditional severe weather setup for North Central Kansas, with various pros and cons for/against robust activity. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided a fair distance south of a vigorous shortwave trough swinging across the Dakotas towards northern MN, resulting in fairly limited forcing aloft. Also working against convection (especially widespread severe) was a plume of warm mid level temperatures, with 700 millibar values of 12-14C promoting a healthy cap. On the other hand, low-level forcing was seasonably-strong, as a well-defined cold front slid southeastward into the area during the evening. Ahead of this boundary, a significantly-unstable airmass awaited, featuring temperatures in the upper 80s-low 90s F/dewpoints upper 60s-mid 70s F, yielding impressive mixed-layer CAPE up to around 4500 J/kg. This extreme instability, in the presence of sufficient deep-layer wind shear around 35 knots, clearly fostered a mesoscale environment capable of stout convection.

event_narrative: The ASOS at the Springfield-Branson National Airport recorded a 58 mph wind gust.
episode_narrative: A strong cold front moved across the region during the late afternoon and evening, and interacted with an unstable air mass and strong vertical wind shear to produce several rounds of strong to severe storms. Widespread wind gusts over 60 mph were reported across the region. The greatest damage occurred near Osage Beach and St. Robert, where straight-line wind gusts over 70 mph produced wind damage at a strip mall and damaged or destroyed manufactured homes.

event_narrative: KDVN observed winds.

A rapidly intensifying low pressure system advanced through the western Great Lakes and eventually spun up toward James Bay. This pushed a cold front across the area during the latter half of November 15. Along the cold front, shallow convection developed with widespread non-severe hail and widespread wind gusts over 60 mph. In the wake of the front, a second and longer-lasting period of non-convective high winds persisted through much of the evening and into the overnight east of Lake Ontario. Widespread damage was reported from both the thunderstorm winds and non-thunderstorm winds. Lake Erie topped 11.13 feet at Buffalo due to the first seiche with the frontal boundary thunderstorms then secondarily topped 10.34 feet with the non-convective wind increase in the evening. This resulted in flooding and some evacuations in Angola, Hamburg, and the Old First Ward in Buffalo. Selected peak wind gusts during the afternoon and evening include 60 mph at Wellsville, 69 mph in Fredonia, 69 mph at the Buffalo Coast Guard, 67 mph at the Buffalo Niagara International Airport, 58 mph in Batavia, 58 mph at Fort Drum, 60 mph in Brockport, 62 mph at Niagara Falls Airport, and 59 mph in Warsaw.

event_narrative: Measured by a Weatherflow gauge.
episode_narrative: Strong low pressure moved through the Great Lakes on November 15, 2020. As it did so, it pushed a warm front through the mid-Atlantic during the late morning and early afternoon hours, causing unseasonably warm conditions to develop. Strong mid and upper level dynamics associated with this low pressure caused linear convection to develop ahead of its associated cold front early in the day. While instability ahead of the front was very limited, the strong frontal forcing combined with extreme wind fields allowed two primary lines of convection to form and produce severe convective wind gusts as they moved east. One of these lines tracked into the eastern mid-Atlantic and towards the coast during the evening hours. It produced widespread wind gusts of around 60 mph, with a number of reports of downed trees and power lines and localized property damage across the region.

event_narrative: In Westford, an amateur radio operator reported a wind gust to 64 mph at 1045 PM EST.  A tree was reported down on Groton Road in Westford around 1040 PM EST...time approximate.
episode_narrative: A warm front moved through southern New England in the evening, followed by strong to damaging wind gusts.  A cold front then moved through late in the evening, accompanied by a fine line of thunderstorms, which also produced some damaging winds.

event_narrative: The Mesonet Station FW1021 recorded a wind gust of 58 mph.
episode_narrative: A strong cold front moved across the region during the late afternoon and evening, and interacted with an unstable air mass and strong vertical wind shear to produce several rounds of strong to severe storms. Widespread wind gusts over 60 mph were reported across the region. The greatest damage occurred near Osage Beach and St. Robert, where straight-line wind gusts over 70 mph produced wind damage at a strip mall and damaged or destroyed manufactured homes.

episode_narrative: A cold front during the late afternoon and early evening hours slashed into an unstable airmass with 2000-3000 J/kg MLCAPE and 30-35 knots of 0-6 km shear. Scattered thunderstorms developed with the thick CAPE profile supportive of large hail and over 1000 J/kg DCAPE resulting in occasional damaging wind.

episode_narrative: A strong jet streak moved across Montana and North Dakota during the afternoon and early evening, providing enough lift to overcome a lid of warmer temperatures aloft across central South Dakota. Storms progressed east and southeast and utilized drying within the elevated layer to generate enough cooling to produce hail, and environmental deep-layer shear of 45 to 55 knots to organize into short bowing segments.

event_narrative: Wind gust was measured by a personal weather station. Crop damage is an estimate from insured losses. Information provided by the United States Department of Agriculture.
episode_narrative: Continued warm air advection and the advancement of steep mid-level lapse rates brought MLCAPE up to 2000 J/kg.  Storms evolved into small bowing segments with deep-layer shear up to 50 knots and DCAPE values over 1000 J/kg while moving from south central to east central South Dakota.
